classifications.note: Fissile isotopes: ²³⁵U, ²³⁹Pu, ²³³U (fission with thermal neutrons). Fertile isotopes: ²³⁸U, ²³²Th (convert to fissile). Thermal fission: slow neutrons (0.025 eV), high cross section. Fast fission: high-energy neutrons (>1 MeV). Average neutrons per fission: ~2.5 for ²³⁵U. Fission products: medium-mass nuclei, typically asymmetric split.

principles.principle: Nuclear Fission Mechanism and Chain Reactions
principles.statement: Nuclear fission involves the splitting of heavy nuclei through several key processes: Fission Mechanism: A heavy nucleus captures a neutron, forming a compound nucleus in an excited state; The nucleus becomes unstable and deforms into a dumbbell shape; Coulomb repulsion overcomes nuclear forces, causing the nucleus to split; Typically produces two medium-mass fission fragments (asymmetric split) plus 2-3 prompt neutrons; Energy release ~200 MeV per fission. Energy Release and Products: Total energy ~200 MeV per fission distributed as: Kinetic energy of fragments: ~165 MeV (83%); Kinetic energy of neutrons: ~5 MeV (2.5%); Instantaneous gamma rays: ~7 MeV (3.5%); Beta particles from fragments: ~8 MeV (4%); Gamma rays from fragments: ~7 MeV (3.5%); Neutrinos: ~11 MeV (5.5%); Fission fragments are neutron-rich and undergo beta decay chains. Chain Reactions and Criticality: Each fission produces neutrons that can induce further fissions; Neutron multiplication factor k: k = 1 (critical: steady reaction), k > 1 (supercritical: growing reaction), k < 1 (subcritical: dying reaction); Critical mass: minimum mass for sustained chain reaction; Depends on geometry, purity, and neutron reflectors. Neutron Moderation: Fast neutrons (∼2 MeV) from fission need slowing for efficient ²³⁵U fission; Moderators (water, graphite) slow neutrons to thermal energies (0.025 eV); Thermal neutrons have much higher fission cross sections; Delayed neutrons (from fission product decay) are crucial for reactor control. Fissile vs Fertile Materials: Fissile: can fission with thermal neutrons (²³⁵U, ²³⁹Pu, ²³³U); Fertile: can be converted to fissile materials (²³⁸U → ²³⁹Pu, ²³²Th → ²³³U); Breeding: converting fertile to fissile materials in reactors. Applications: Nuclear reactors: controlled chain reactions for power; Nuclear weapons: uncontrolled supercritical chain reactions; Radioisotope production: fission products for medical/industrial use; Research: neutron sources for scientific studies.
principles.application: Calculate energy release from fission. Analyze chain reaction conditions. Determine critical mass parameters. Understand reactor control mechanisms. Predict fission product distributions. Apply to power generation design.
principles.example: ²³⁵U + n → ¹⁴¹Ba + ⁹²Kr + 3n + 200 MeV. Typical reactor: k=1.000, precisely controlled. Nuclear weapon: rapid k>>1 supercritical assembly.
principles.analogy: Like splitting a large, unstable business - when it divides (fission), it releases capital (energy) and spawns new managers (neutrons) who can go split other unstable businesses; if each split produces enough new managers, the process spreads exponentially (chain reaction); control depends on how many managers stay in the system

worked_examples.title: Fission Energy Calculation
worked_examples.problem: Calculate the energy released in the fission: ²³⁵U + n → ¹⁴¹Ba + ⁹²Kr + 3n. Masses: ²³⁵U=235.043923 u, n=1.008665 u, ¹⁴¹Ba=140.914411 u, ⁹²Kr=91.926156 u.

step_by_step.explanation: This specific channel gives 173 MeV. Average over all possible fission products is ~200 MeV. Difference due to varying fission fragment combinations.

worked_examples.final_answer: Energy released = 173.2 MeV for this specific fission channel. Typical average fission energy ~200 MeV.

image.caption: Fission energy calculation from mass defect

worked_examples.title: Critical Mass Estimation
worked_examples.problem: Estimate critical mass for ²³⁵U sphere without reflector. Given: density=19 g/cm³, fission cross section σ_f=585 barns, average neutrons per fission ν=2.43, neutron mean free path λ=17 cm.

step_by_step.explanation: For bare sphere, critical when: k = νP ≈ 1, where P is non-leakage probability
For sphere: P ≈ 1/(1 + (π/Λ)²R²) where Λ is diffusion length. With λ=17 cm, estimate Λ~20 cm.
Actual critical mass for ²³⁵U sphere ~52 kg. Our estimate is reasonable; differences due to simplifications in neutron transport.

worked_examples.final_answer: Estimated critical mass ≈ 35 kg for bare ²³⁵U sphere. Actual value ~52 kg. Demonstrates critical mass calculation principles.

image.caption: Critical mass estimation for nuclear fission

sections.introduction: Process of light nuclear combining, stellar nucleosynthesis, Coulomb barrier overcoming, and energy production in stars and fusion devices.

key_concept.definition: Nuclear fusion, Coulomb barrier, Thermonuclear reactions, Fusion cross section, Lawson criterion, Ignition temperature, Stellar nucleosynthesis, Fusion fuels, Plasma confinement, Magnetic confinement.
key_concept.context: Nuclear fusion involves combining light nuclei to form heavier elements, releasing enormous energy that powers stars and requires extreme temperatures to overcome electrostatic repulsion.

image.caption: Nuclear fusion mechanism and stellar energy production

classifications.value: Classification based on reaction types and physical conditions
classifications.behavior: Different fusion reactions occur under specific conditions: D-T fusion has highest cross section at lower temperatures; p-p chain dominates in Sun-like stars; CNO cycle operates in hotter stars; each reaction has characteristic temperature requirements and energy outputs

examples.explanation: D + T → ⁴He + n + 17.6 MeV, the most accessible fusion reaction for energy production

image.caption: D-T fusion reaction and energy distribution

examples.explanation: Fusion processes in stars creating elements up to iron

image.caption: Element creation through fusion in stars

classifications.note: Main fusion reactions: D+T→⁴He+n+17.6 MeV; D+D→T+p+4.0 MeV or ³He+n+3.3 MeV; D+³He→⁴He+p+18.3 MeV; p+p→D+e⁺+ν+1.44 MeV. Temperature requirements: D-T: ~100 million K; D-D: ~500 million K; p-p: ~15 million K (Sun core). Coulomb barrier: electrostatic repulsion between positively charged nuclei.

principles.principle: Nuclear Fusion Processes and Stellar Energy
principles.statement: Nuclear fusion involves light nuclei combining to form heavier elements through several key processes: Fusion Mechanism and Coulomb Barrier: Light nuclei must overcome electrostatic repulsion (Coulomb barrier) to get within range of nuclear forces; At stellar temperatures, nuclei have Maxwell-Boltzmann energy distribution with small high-energy tail; Quantum tunneling allows fusion even below barrier energy; Fusion probability depends on energy, cross section, and tunneling probability. Key Fusion Reactions: Deuterium-Tritium: D + T → ⁴He (3.5 MeV) + n (14.1 MeV) + 17.6 MeV (most accessible); Deuterium-Deuterium: D + D → T (1.0 MeV) + p (3.0 MeV) + 4.0 MeV or → ³He (0.8 MeV) + n (2.5 MeV) + 3.3 MeV; Deuterium-Helium-3: D + ³He → ⁴He (3.6 MeV) + p (14.7 MeV) + 18.3 MeV (aneutronic); Proton-Proton: p + p → D + e⁺ + ν + 1.44 MeV (slow, weak interaction). Stellar Nucleosynthesis: Main sequence stars: p-p chain or CNO cycle converting H to He; Red giants: triple-alpha process forming carbon: 3⁴He → ¹²C + 7.3 MeV; Massive stars: successive fusion creating elements up to iron; Supernovae: neutron capture processes creating heavier elements. Fusion Energy Balance: Energy gain must overcome: Radiation losses (bremsstrahlung, synchrotron); Conduction and convection losses; Energy required to heat fuel; Lawson criterion: nτ > 10²⁰ s/m³ for D-T fusion (n=density, τ=confinement time); Ignition temperature: ~100 million K for D-T fusion. Fusion in Laboratory: Magnetic confinement: tokamaks, stellarators using magnetic fields to contain plasma; Inertial confinement: lasers or particle beams compressing fusion fuel; Current challenges: achieving break-even (Q=1) and net energy gain. Why Iron is the Endpoint: Binding energy per nucleon peaks at iron-56; Fusion releases energy up to iron; Beyond iron, fusion consumes energy; This explains stellar evolution endpoints and supernova nucleosynthesis.
principles.application: Calculate fusion energy yields. Analyze stellar fusion processes. Understand fusion reactor requirements. Compare different fusion fuels. Apply Lawson criterion. Design fusion experiments.
principles.example: Sun's core: T=15 million K, p-p chain dominant. ITER reactor: goal Q=10, D-T fusion at 150 million K. Hydrogen bomb: uses fission to initiate D-T fusion.
principles.analogy: Like trying to push two strong magnets together - they repel strongly at first (Coulomb barrier), but if you push hard enough (high temperature) or get lucky with a precise approach (quantum tunneling), they suddenly snap together (fusion) releasing the energy you stored plus extra binding energy

worked_examples.title: Fusion Energy Calculation
worked_examples.problem: Calculate the energy released in D-T fusion: D + T → ⁴He + n. Masses: D=2.014102 u, T=3.016049 u, ⁴He=4.002603 u, n=1.008665 u.

step_by_step.explanation: Neutron gets 14.1 MeV (80%), alpha gets 3.5 MeV (20%) due to momentum conservation.

worked_examples.final_answer: Energy released = 17.59 MeV per D-T fusion. Neutron: 14.1 MeV, Alpha: 3.5 MeV.

image.caption: Fusion energy calculation from mass defect

worked_examples.title: Lawson Criterion Application
worked_examples.problem: A fusion experiment has plasma density n=10²⁰ m⁻³ and confinement time τ=0.5 s. Temperature T=100 million K. Check if it meets Lawson criterion for D-T fusion (required nτ>10²⁰ s/m³). Calculate the energy gain if fusion power P_fusion=50 MW and input power P_input=40 MW.

step_by_step.explanation: Required nτ > 10²⁰ s/m³, actual 5×10¹⁹ s/m³ = 0.5×10²⁰, so criterion NOT met (need improvement)
Q=1.25 means 25% more energy out than in, but this doesn't account for all system losses. True break-even requires Q>5 typically.
To meet Lawson: increase density to 2×10²⁰ m⁻³ or confinement to 1 s, or both.

worked_examples.final_answer: nτ=5×10¹⁹ s/m³, below Lawson criterion (10²⁰). Q=1.25, but system not self-sustaining. Need improved confinement or density.

image.caption: Lawson criterion for fusion energy break-even

classifications.note: Fission reactors: 440 operational worldwide, ~10% global electricity. Fusion reactors: experimental (ITER, JET), not yet commercial. Nuclear weapons: fission (atomic bombs), fusion (thermonuclear). Fuel resources: fission: uranium limited (~100 years); fusion: deuterium abundant (millions of years). Waste: fission: long-lived radioactive waste; fusion: low-activated materials, shorter-lived waste.

principles.principle: Applications, Challenges, and Comparisons of Fission and Fusion
principles.statement: Fission and fusion have distinct applications, challenges, and characteristics: Fission Applications: Nuclear power: 440 reactors worldwide providing ~10% global electricity; Types: PWR (pressurized water), BWR (boiling water), CANDU (heavy water); Nuclear weapons: fission bombs and primaries for thermonuclear weapons; Research reactors: neutron sources for science, medicine, industry; Radioisotope production: medical isotopes (⁹⁹Mo/⁹⁹ᵐTc), industrial radiography; Nuclear propulsion: naval vessels, space probes (RTGs). Fusion Applications: Experimental reactors: tokamaks (ITER, JET), stellarators, laser facilities; Future power plants: potential for abundant, clean electricity; Thermonuclear weapons: hydrogen bombs using fission-initiated fusion; Stellar energy: understanding star formation and evolution; Space propulsion concepts: fusion rockets for rapid interplanetary travel. Comparative Analysis: Energy density: Fusion ~4× fission per reaction, but fission fuel heavier; Fuel abundance: Fission uranium limited, fusion deuterium virtually unlimited; Waste products: Fission produces long-lived transuranics, fusion produces mainly short-lived activation products; Safety: Fission has criticality and meltdown risks, fusion has no chain reaction risk; Proliferation: Fission materials weapons-usable, fusion materials less proliferative; Technological maturity: Fission commercial, fusion experimental. Fission Challenges: Radioactive waste management requiring geological disposal; Safety concerns (Chernobyl, Fukushima-type accidents); Proliferation risks of plutonium production; Limited uranium resources; Decommissioning costs and complexity. Fusion Challenges: Achieving and sustaining plasma confinement; Materials surviving neutron radiation; Achieving net energy gain (Q>1); Tritium fuel breeding and handling; Economic competitiveness; Scale and complexity of reactors. Environmental Impacts: Fission: CO₂-free but mining impacts, thermal pollution, waste issues; Fusion: minimal long-lived waste, no CO₂, but tritium handling; Both: land use, construction impacts. Future Prospects: Advanced fission: Generation IV reactors, thorium cycles, small modular reactors; Fusion development: ITER (2025), DEMO, commercial plants possibly 2050+; Hybrid systems: fusion-fission combinations; Both technologies potentially important for decarbonized energy future.
principles.application: Compare fission and fusion characteristics. Evaluate energy system options. Understand nuclear safety principles. Analyze waste management strategies. Assess proliferation concerns. Design nuclear systems.
principles.example: ITER fusion project: goal Q=10, 500 MW fusion power. Current PWR: 1 GWe output, 3% enriched uranium. Fukushima accident: meltdown from loss of cooling. Hydrogen bomb: fission primary compresses fusion secondary.
principles.analogy: Like two ways to get heat from wood - splitting large logs (fission) gives immediate usable pieces but creates splinters and waste; combining small twigs (fusion) requires more effort to start but burns cleaner with less waste; we've mastered log-splitting but are still learning the best way to bundle twigs for a sustained fire

worked_examples.title: Energy Density Comparison
worked_examples.problem: Compare energy density of fission and fusion with chemical fuels. Given: gasoline=46 MJ/kg, ²³⁵U fission=200 MeV/fission, D-T fusion=17.6 MeV/fusion. Calculate energy per kg for each.

step_by_step.explanation: Average mass per reaction = (2+3)/2 = 2.5 u. N = (1000/2.5×1.66×10⁻²⁷) = 2.41×10²⁹ reactions/kg
Gasoline: 46 MJ/kg; Fission: 82 TJ/kg (1.8 million × gasoline); Fusion: 680 TJ/kg (15 million × gasoline); Fusion ~8× fission energy density

worked_examples.final_answer: Energy density: Gasoline=46 MJ/kg, Fission=82 TJ/kg, Fusion=680 TJ/kg. Fusion has ~8× higher energy density than fission, millions × chemical fuels.

image.caption: Energy density comparison of different energy sources

worked_examples.title: Reactor Power Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A fission reactor produces 1 GWe electrical at 33% efficiency. Calculate: (a) Thermal power, (b) Fissions per second, (c) ²³⁵U consumption per year, (d) Compare with coal plant equivalent.

step_by_step.explanation: Mass ²³⁵U per fission = 235 u = 235 × 1.66×10⁻²⁷ = 3.90×10⁻²⁵ kg
Coal energy ~24 MJ/kg. For 1 GWe at 33% efficiency: coal needed = (1×10⁹/0.33) / (24×10⁶) = 126 kg/s = 4 million tonnes/year

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) 3.03 GW thermal, (b) 9.46×10¹⁹ fissions/s, (c) 1.16 tonnes ²³⁵U/year, (d) Equivalent coal: 4 million tonnes/year. Shows nuclear efficiency.

image.caption: Nuclear reactor power and fuel consumption calculations

summary: Nuclear fission splits heavy nuclei (uranium, plutonium) releasing ~200 MeV per fission through neutron-induced chain reactions, used in power plants and weapons. Nuclear fusion combines light nuclei (deuterium, tritium) releasing ~17 MeV per fusion, requiring extreme temperatures to overcome Coulomb repulsion, powering stars and pursued for clean energy. Fission is technologically mature but produces long-lived radioactive waste; fusion offers abundant fuel and less waste but remains experimentally challenging. Both processes convert mass to energy via E=Δmc², with fusion having higher energy density per mass. Applications include electricity generation, medical isotopes, scientific research, and national security, with ongoing development of advanced fission reactors and experimental fusion devices like ITER.
